text:
<@U9V8ZQVEY> how much are flights to NZ?
The Australian flights are all unbelievably high because the Australian goverment has capped the number of people allowed to arrive by air, and so to make it worth their wild the airlines are only offering first class seats.
did NZ do the same?

elements.text:
how much are flights to NZ?
The Australian flights are all unbelievably high because the Australian goverment has capped the number of people allowed to arrive by air, and so to make it worth their wild the airlines are only offering first class seats.
did NZ do the same?

text: Hmm. It doesn't look like to be the case, and I haven't heard anything about airlines only offering first class etc.

elements.text: Hmm. It doesn't look like to be the case, and I haven't heard anything about airlines only offering first class etc.

text: Return trip from AKL to Frankfurt for Jan would cost about 2000-3500 NZD it looks, which is not the cheapest, but definitely not unreasonable.

elements.text: Return trip from AKL to Frankfurt for Jan would cost about 2000-3500 NZD it looks, which is not the cheapest, but definitely not unreasonable.

text: Yeah, that’s not too bad. A bit higher than usual but if it was before Christmas, I would say it was expected.

elements.text: Yeah, that’s not too bad. A bit higher than usual but if it was before Christmas, I would say it was expected.

text: Yeah. In normal times the Christmas/New Years period is usually quite expensive as well.

elements.text: Yeah. In normal times the Christmas/New Years period is usually quite expensive as well.

text: NZ does have a limit on the number incoming people, determined by the capacity of the managed isolation system (you have to have a booking). I don't know how many people are arriving every day, but I think it's on the order of hundreds or even thousands. So I think they can fill an airplane easily, they have just reduced the number of flights most likely.

elements.text: NZ does have a limit on the number incoming people, determined by the capacity of the managed isolation system (you have to have a booking). I don't know how many people are arriving every day, but I think it's on the order of hundreds or even thousands. So I think they can fill an airplane easily, they have just reduced the number of flights most likely.

text: Ok, it looks like the capacity it 4500, for 14 days. So they should be able to take in 320 people every day, on average.

elements.text: Ok, it looks like the capacity it 4500, for 14 days. So they should be able to take in 320 people every day, on average.

text:
1,025 _passengers into_ Perth are allowed per week; so 146 per day.
Which running the numbers is actually slightly more per capita than NZ.
Hard to explain why our flights are so expensive then.
Maybe it is because all flights in to NZ go to just a few nearby locations where as Australia needs seperate flights per capital, and so its harder to fill up aircraft to make them worthwild while staying under the limits.

elements.text: passengers into

Hard to explain why our flights are so expensive then.
Maybe it is because all flights in to NZ go to just a few nearby locations where as Australia needs seperate flights per capital, and so its harder to fill up aircraft to make them worthwild while staying under the limits.

text: Yeah, could be. I'm pretty sure that all the international flights come only to Auckland in NZ at the moment.

elements.text: Yeah, could be. I'm pretty sure that all the international flights come only to Auckland in NZ at the moment.

text: It looks like you can get reasonably priced flights from Europe to Sydney.

elements.text: It looks like you can get reasonably priced flights from Europe to Sydney.

text: that would make sense, since Sydney is letting in 3000 per week

elements.text: that would make sense, since Sydney is letting in 3000 per week

text:
WA is super-paranoid right now, so I can’t see them relaxing and taking in any more people regardless of capacity.
Paranoids not the right word. Is it still called paranoid if you are right?

elements.text:
WA is super-paranoid right now, so I can’t see them relaxing and taking in any more people regardless of capacity.
Paranoids not the right word. Is it still called paranoid if you are right?

text: And you also can't travel from other states to WA without quarantine either I guess? So flying to Sydney and taking a domestic flight or driving after quarantine there is not an option either?

elements.text: And you also can't travel from other states to WA without quarantine either I guess? So flying to Sydney and taking a domestic flight or driving after quarantine there is not an option either?

text: Of course, there's the new outbreak there now. But even before that WA still hadn't opened up the borders?

elements.text: Of course, there's the new outbreak there now. But even before that WA still hadn't opened up the borders?

text:
correct in general.
though the quarantine for domestic can be at home.
So can fly to Syndey then quarantine there in hotel for 2 weeks, then domestic to WA, then quarantine at home for 2 weeks.

Except not right now, as WA has fully closed its boarders to NSW.
They were open to NSW for about 3 weeks?

elements.text:

though the quarantine for domestic can be at home.

text: WA would probably fully close its boarders to overseas if it could, but people find that a bit too close to denying the fundermental citizenship right of entry

elements.text: WA would probably fully close its boarders to overseas if it could, but people find that a bit too close to denying the fundermental citizenship right of entry

text: Not sure how much this veers into politics, but is there a reason why WA is seemingly so much more "paranoid" than the rest of Australia? Because I have heard that before that it tends to be much more stricter.

elements.text: Not sure how much this veers into politics, but is there a reason why WA is seemingly so much more "paranoid" than the rest of Australia? Because I have heard that before that it tends to be much more stricter.

text:
One part is Western Australia has seccesssionist tendencies.
(WA voted to seceed in 1933; a within the last decade the WA branch of the Liberal (i.e. conservative) party affirmed that seccession is something they believe in.)
While there hasn’t been a referendum for it in my lifetime, the sentiment is there.

Another is they have had basically no community transmission of covid ever.
Like a total of something like 14 cases that they didn’t trace directly to someone from overseas.
People have no idea how bad it is and I guess tend to the extreme imagine of it, since they haven’t seen it. (which i think is better than the reverse)

And the current state premier is absolutely riding the fact that there is no covid, and kinda deserves to. It’s working, the economy is going great, noone is dying etc. what more could you want.
and every time he announces restrictions, that basically stokes up his supports (which is most people).
because it reminds them how much better WA is.

Also the current state goverment is Labor, where as the federal goverment is Liberal, and so sticking it to the Liberal federal goverment trying to tell the state to open borders is like free value.

text: That's interesting, thanks! Sounds a little bit like NZ in this respect.
